Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Market Analysis and Customer Needs Identification for the Commercialization of a High-Speed Disconnect Switch
Award.AbstractNarration:
The electric power distribution grid enables us to have a convenient and reliable access to electrical power for our daily needs. Electric power is used for lighting, HVAC, communication, transportation, medicine, manufacturing, defense, and many other vital applications. For the United States to remain competitive, there must be a secure, reliable, and adaptable electrical power grid. Aging systems, hardware failures, and interruptions in service have immediate and severe impacts on our economy and quality of life. It is for these reasons among others that there is a push from the community to improve these aging systems and provide the society with next generation electrical power distribution grids. However, for this to be viable, it is imperative that new enabling technologies, on which these systems can be built, are developed. A critical design problem in any power system is how to handle electrical faults within the system that come from internal failures or external environmental causes, e.g. trees falling on power lines. Due to requirements in the next-gen power systems being developed, the conventional methods and technologies, such as conventional circuit breakers, are insufficient and poorly suited to the demands of future highly adaptable and flexible power grids as they are currently envisioned. The high speed disconnect switch that this team has developed has the potential to fill this need and provide a foundational technology on which these next-gen electric power distribution systems can be built.

A novel ultra-fast low-loss switch, for which this proposal seeks to perform commercialization research, has been developed in response to the paradigm shift currently occurring in how terrestrial domestic distribution power systems are designed. Ultra-fast low-loss switches are seen as a key enabling technology for these dynamic and highly flexible systems. The ultra-fast disconnect switch invented by the team presents a novel, compact, and elegant solution for a problem that is fast becoming more and more relevant in power grid design. With its novel design, the switch is able to accomplish the several key requirements necessary for it to be a viable solution. Due to smart material selection and a thermally efficient design, the switch is able to carry load currents of several hundred amps with very low losses while closed. With its unique use of integrated piezoelectric actuators the switch is able to open and electrically isolate within several hundred microseconds. The use of vacuum technologies gives it the ability to withstand distribution level system voltages less than a millisecond after opening without interrupting current (current interruption is done by the power electronic converters in the next-gen systems). In preliminary discussions with major industry players who supply the electric utility market, the novel design was met with interest. By participating in the I-Corps program, the team hopes to understand how to best act upon this interest from the primary market and to also determine if there are secondary markets that can be explored and served.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Public Project Summary

Starting July 1st 2015, Entrepreneurial Lead, Chris Widener, Principle Investigator, Dr. Lukas Graber, and Industry Mentor, Dr. Lawrence Tinker, embarked on a 6 month effort, as I-Corp Team 515, to determine the market and commercial potential for a novel 15,000 Volt high-speed disconnect switch co-invented by Graber and Widener the previous year and developed as an enabling technology for next generation utility scale electrical power systems.

Entering the program, the team was under the assumption that there was an extensive need by electrical utilities, as well as the companies who supplied them with electric power products, for their ultra fast switch. It was the team’s goal to explore this market as well as explore the needs of the Navy, who are currently building all-electric battleships with medium voltage micro grids similar to the terrestrial power distribution grids used by electric utilities.

After going through the rigorous business canvas methodology training and performing customer discovery as taught by the program, Widener and Graber found that, with the exception of the several key utilities servicing densely populated cities, the market was not as far reaching as originally thought.  However, within this select group of progressive utilities, there appears to be a need for hybrid circuit breakers, transfer switches, and fault current limiters, which depends on the development of an enabling technology, namely a low loss, remotely reclosable, ultra-fast switching method to further increase power grid reliability and resiliency. To be in the right position to fill this need, Widener and Graber’s novel prototype would need to be augmented to fulfill voltage and current requirements and its functionality proven in a field deployed application.  Size was also a very serious concern for these customers, with 36 inches by 106 inches by 95 inches being the desired cubic dimensions (0.9×2.7×2.4 m3) of the final device package.

Widener and Graber also spent time investigating the needs of the Navy and were able to determine the needs were similar to that of the electric utilities, except that the Navy is in need of a DC switch instead of an AC one. After extensive conversations with program and funding officers within the Navy’s SBIR and STTR programs, it was discovered that a STTR was to be released in the middle of December 2015 with an emphasis on developing ultra-fast switchgear and a new protection scheme for the all electric ships.

Though the team ultimately decided on a No-Go decision on establishing a new company at the end of the 6 months, this was with the understanding that with several goals accomplished, this decision might possibly change: One, more fundamental research was needed to improve the nominal current carrying capacity and short circuit current rating of the switch. Two, a prototype with these improvements would need to be developed and its functionality proven in a field deployed application.
